5. Liberty to apply.
My reasons for making these orders are set out in Procter v Kalivis [2009] FCA 1518. On 25 February 2010, the respondents filed a Further Amended List of Documents verified by affidavits of all respondents. The applicants pressed their application in paragraph 1 of the notice of motion for leave to cross examine the respondents in relation to the Further Amended List of Documents.

In my previous decision in this proceeding, I set out the relevant principles as to the circumstances in which an affidavit of a discovery may be challenged and the circumstances in which a party may be granted leave to cross-examine on an affidavit of discovery: Procter v Kalivis [2009] FCA 1518 ; (2009) 263 ALR 461 at 467-469 [29] - [40]. I will not repeat what I said about those principles. In the ordinary case, the affidavit of discovery is conclusive: Mulley v Manifold [1959] HCA 23 ; (1959) 103 CLR 341 at 343 per Menzies J. Cross-examination will be allowed only in very limited circumstances. In my opinion, this is not a case in which cross-examination on the affidavits of discovery should be allowed.

The applicants' application was refined as the submissions proceeded. The applicants accepted that, at this stage, they could not press for an order for cross-examination of the first, third and fourth respondents. That concession was correctly made and I refer generally to my discussion of the circumstances in which cross-examination may be ordered in Procter v Kalivis [2009] FCA 1518 at [35] - [41].
